title: How many countries will have 100,000 or more deaths attributed to COVID-19 as of 30 April 2021?
preds: Unlikely that Germany or any others will develop significant wave of deaths in time remaining

Continuing to adjust toward 100% on "7 or 8" as those countries that either are approaching the 100,000 threshold do not appear that they will cross it and no reporting revisions from countries that I suspect are under reporting have occurred.
Going to be close, but I don't think any others will go over in 5 days.

Maintaining my forecast for now.  Watching a couple of countries, but those countries do not appear to be surging or surging enough to cross the 100,000 threshold by the end of the week.  Continue to account for the possibility of an unforeseen situation, such as Turkey being called out for inaccurate reporting of COVID deaths.  Will probably creep closer to 100% for "7 or 8" throughout the week.
we are less than a week away- 9 seems like a stretch now

With a week to go it seems highly unlikely a ninth country will cross the 100,000 deaths mark, but still accounting for the slim possibility a country significantly revises their numbers.  I continue to examine Turkey, which is experiencing a major surge.  They have had 4.5 million COVID cases, but only 37,329 deaths from COVID.  Unless Turkey has some new medical technology to respond to COVID or a genetic resilience to the virus they should have a death count significantly higher, probably above 100,000.  But, the rules are the rules for these projections.  I will slowly move towards 100% "7 or 8" over the next week.

Currently there are eight countries with more than 100,000 COVID deaths.  So, the question is, will any other country cross that threshold in the next week and a halfish?  The closest would appear to be Germany (81,382) and Spain (77,364).  Either country would have to see a major surge in COVID deaths in the next week to cross the threshold, which is probably highly unlikely.  Need to also account for the possibility that the true number of COVID deaths is revised in a county over the next week (I am looking at you Turkey).

Numerous countries throughout the world lack the health-related resources to deal with COVID-19 and it's consequences, and some are so in need that they cannot provide adequate testing for large swathes of the population. Right now, it is suspected that thousands of people in these nations are dying and aren't even getting recorded because some of these countries lack the means to even log those deaths. Additionally, these nations are last in line to receive the vaccine, which will leave their rates of infection climbing ever higher.[1] Consequently, I predict that there is a 100% chance that 9 or more nations will have 100,000 or more deaths attributed to COVID-19 as of April 30th. [1] https://www.nytimes.com/2021/03/22/world/africa/africa-vaccine-inequality-covid.html
Just letting out the slim probability that I had previously given to the possibility that the number of countries would stay at 6.

Final forecast. Updating from 0/0/0/97/3. It will be 8 countries: US, Brazil, Mexico, India, UK, Italy, Russia, France. They're all already there, and for any other countries to break 100k we'd need one of those retroactive updates, where a big pile of data is suddenly dumped onto the system. Trouble is, the size of the update would have to be 5-10x larger than any such dumps that have occurred in the past. In all cases except Germany and Spain (less likely to have such dumps), the backlog would have to be 50% or more of ALL deaths so far. Plus it would have to happen in the next 11 days. I've done pretty well in this question overall. I don't want to brag (although who can resist a little bit of it?), but rather point out how simple were the heuristics I used to get a very good forecast all the way back in Dec 2020. (You can see it in [1].) On 20 Dec 2020, when I made my first forecast, the crowd was about evenly split between "4" and "5 or 6", with almost no weight given to higher buckets. In contrast, my own forecast gave "8" the highest weight. (I forecast each individual outcome, not just the question buckets.) I had "8" at 35%, as well as "7" and "9" at around 25% each. Moreover, I gave a probability to each individual country; and every country I gave >50% reached 100k, whereas no country I gave <50% did so. Even better, countries reached 100k roughly in the order of the probabilities I assigned them. E.g. I gave Italy and UK 90%, and they reached 100k long before Russia, which I gave 70% to. And Russia reached 100k three weeks before France, which I gave 60% to. And France, which I gave 60%, reached 100k today, very close to the deadline. Finally, the next highest for me was Germany at 40%, and of all countries which didn't cross 100k, Germany came closest. So overall I feel that in this question I was very well calibrated. No doubt some of this success is "luck". But probably not all of it. The only clear edge that I can see myself having over most is that I actually bothered to give each country its own individual probability, then I wrote a simple program to get the aggregate forecast. With 10+ countries in play you can't really do it by hand or by eyeballing. For the individual probabilities I just looked at where each country was, and how fast it was growing; occasionally I checked on Google which were doing lockdowns; and I made sure countries farther ahead and growing faster had higher odds than countries farther behind and growing slower. That's it. I know little about the politics or news of any country except US and Brazil (which were already over 100k when I started this Q). [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1203846

Para realizar esta predicción, busque información acerca de la cantidad de muertes por coronavirus en distintos países, con lo que encontré una lista con los países con más muertes atribuidas al coronavirus. Dentro de esta lista, hay 7 países que ya tienen más de 100.000 muertes, por lo tanto, con esta información ya se que van a haber 7 o más países. Además, el octavo país con más muertes, Francia, tiene 99.135 muertes y al día de hoy (13 de abril), sumaron 385 muertes, por lo que es muy probable que a fin de mes ya hayan superado las 100.000 muertes, teniendo así 8 países en la lista.
El noveno país con más muertes por coronavirus es Alemania, que registra 78.796 muertes, habiendo sumado 296 al día de hoy. Le siguen España con 76.5255 y Colombia con 66.156 muertes. De esta forma, veo muy dificil que puedan haber 9 o más países con más de 100.000 muertes, ya que, para el caso de Alemania (que se asoma como el noveno país), si tuviera una tasa de 300 muertes diarias por 18 días, se sumarían un poco más de 5.000 muertes, haciendo imposible que se llegue a un total de 100.000.
Con esto, mi pronóstico es que si o si van a haber 7 u 8 países.
Datos extraídos de Wikipedia, The New York Times y JHU CSSE COVID-19 DATA

With 23 days remaining for this question's tallying to close - 7 countries have already crossed the threshold of 100k deaths according to the WHO: US, Brazil, Mexico, India, UK, Italy, Russia. France is a few thousand away from crossing (currently @ ~97k) and currently has a 7 day death rate average of 276, which if maintained would push it above 100k within the stated timeframe (far earlier). Given that France is going through another wave of infection, reaching this number of deaths seems all but certain given past patterns of covid surges. The countries with the next two highest death tolls - Germany @ 77k and Spain @ 75 k - would need their average death rates for the next 23 days to increase by a factor of 9.5x and 12.4x respectively to cross the 100k threshold. Given they both seem to be in transmission plateaus (new cases / capita), this appears highly unlikely. Therefore, by the end of April the total number of countries with more than 100k reported covid deaths would be 7 (current number) + france, for a total of 8.

Next on the list are Germany and Spain with approximately 77,000 cases and there are no indications that this will increase dramatically the coming weeks.
Then you have Colombia with approximately 64,000 deaths so far and also unlikely to have a massive increase in the next few weeks.
Last to review is Iran with 63,500 deaths and there might be a question whether they release true data. Even if this country will adjust their figures, adding so 36,500 additional deaths this months is very unlikely.

Germany and Spain death rates aren't increasing enough daily, given recent restrictions.  Leaving a low outside chance for uptick in cases there or in Colombia or Iran which is starting to see an uptick in deaths reported.

The rise across Europe is a concern (https://www.theguardian.com/world/2021/mar/17/europe-at-the-start-of-a-third-wave-of-covid-experts-warn), however the number of deaths required is extremely high. Poland would need around 2,000 per day, a number not even reached by the UK at its peak. 
Germany would need the best part of 1,000 cases per day, similar to its peak. That would represent a catastrophically poor performance over the next month, especially given that vaccines have been rolled out to the most vulnerable (https://www.statista.com/statistics/1195560/coronavirus-covid-19-vaccinations-number-germany) and the weather is improving.
Is there a chance that Germany or another breaks the 100,000 mark? Yes. Either by a seriously unfortunate event or, arguably more likely, a nation changes how it has counted the deaths retrospectively and the numbers jump up by a significant amount. There is a chance, but I don't see it as a 1% chance given how far into the pandemic we are and I've not heard of a single country change methods retrospectively since the UK (https://www.reuters.com/article/uk-factcheck-data-idUSKBN29J2TH). Most interestingly, that only changed numbers by up to 6,000, no nearly enough to push any of the remaining countries to 100,000.

Spain and Germany have an outside chance but have robust vaccination programs going. Even with increasing infection rates, probably won't eclipse 100k. Iran is probably there already but reporting inaccurate numbers.
I don't think Spain and Germany will hit 100,000 before April 30.
The fourth surge is upon us, but I don't think any further countries will hit 100,000 by April 30.

Germany is the only question.
Germany's case growth is currently the mirror image of its case decline from winter. If it continues this way, Germany will probably see at most an additional number of deaths that is approximately the same as the number of deaths due to cases from Feb. 10 backwards 32 days to Jan. 9, inclusive, modified by the higher case fatality rate for B.1.1.7. With an approximately 3 week lag in deaths, this translates to the deaths from Jan. 30 through March 3. Germany added 15.0k deaths between Jan. 9 and March 3. However, B.1.1.7 is more deadly (30% to 50%?) than ancestral strains, so the deaths could be a bit higher.
Note that many deaths can be expected to increase dramatically soon, because cases already went up, vaccination rates are low (albeit concentrated among seniors), and so, the deaths are already baked in.
Germany's deaths currently stand at 76.1k. Even with incredible exponential growth in cases and greater case fatality rates due to B.1.1.7, it's probably not possible for Germany to reach 100k cases by April 30.

Update: I realized that elevated deaths in the second half of April in Germany will likely not be sufficient to "make up for" low death levels through mid April. Now through the end of April is unlikely to see an average of 700 cases/day, based on Germany's experience in the fall and winter, even if cases grow exponentially and quickly.

Germany is the only question. If their case numbers continue to increase, they will likely reach more than 100k deaths by the end of April. Case numbers are currently rising at a rate corresponding to doubling about every 2 weeks. If cases continue to rise for the next 2 weeks, then the deaths will follow with a 3 week lag.
Deaths are at 76,303 now, with 34 days to go. That means if there is an average of 697 deaths/day, deaths will exceed 100k by April 30. Right now, there are about 200 deaths/day. Daily deaths will likely be double that, increasing and accelerating by mid April. Then the second half of April could have death rates over 1000/day.

8 countries would seem to be a near certainty. Russia should be there within the next week or two, while France is on track to surpass 100,00 deaths by the time this question closes, even assuming their average deaths per day remain flat at ~200 (unlikely as cases have been steadily increasing for the past two weeks).  Germany is the next closest to surpassing 100,000 deaths and would need to average 700 deaths per day over the next 35 days. There seems to be about a 2 week lag between cases and deaths (last peak in avg. cases per day was on December 24th per Worldometers, while the last peak in avg. deaths per day was on Jan 10), so working backwards two weeks before they last averaged ~700 deaths per day in early February they were averaging around ~18k cases per day. The current 7-day case average is already ~15k, so even assuming no further increase in cases, deaths are likely to increase to around 700 per day over the next two weeks. The question is, will cases continue increasing substantially such that they average 700 deaths per day over the entire next month, rather than just for a few days or weeks?

I don't want to spend a lot of time on this question because it seems easy to outdo the crowd here. So I'll use some quick and dirty heuristics. If a country currently has a weekly death rate >2x higher than it needs to get to 100k, and it's at more than 60k already, I'll give it 90%. I'll downgrade as the death rate gets lower than 2x needed, and as countries are farther away from the 100k mark (which means it would take longer to reach it, leaving time for the new vaccines to be administered to more people). I will only assign probabilities in multiples of 10%, and I will tend to round up because it's winter in all countries in play. Italy: 32.5k to go, need 1.70/week, has 4.41k/week. 90%

The (simple) Python code to calculate the probabilities is below, if anyone is interested. I replaced the indenting spaces with underscores because GJOpen formats away spaces at the beginning of lines. # The context for this block is that we have N independent events, each with its
# own distinct probability of happening, say p1, p2, ... , pN. And we want to
# compute the probability that k of them happen, for 0 <= k <= N. # Inputs:
#   * outcomes: a list [q0, q1, ... , qN] representing the probabilities that we
#               get 0, ... , N successes for some N events E_1,...,E_N.
#   * pSuccess: the probability of E_{N+1}, which is independent of E_1,...,E_N.
# Output:
#   * a list [r0, r1, ... , r{N+1}] representing the probabilities that we get
#     0, ..., N+1 successes among E_1, ..., E_{N+1}.
def AddEvent(outcomes, pSuccess):
__if outcomes == []:
____return [1-pSuccess, pSuccess]
__N = len(outcomes)
__outcomesIfNo = [(1-pSuccess)*outcomes[k] for k in range(0,N)] + [0]
__outcomesIfYes = [0] + [pSuccess*outcomes[k] for k in range(0,N)]
__return [outcomesIfNo[k] + outcomesIfYes[k] for k in range(0,N+1)] # Inputs:
#   * eventProbabilities: a list of the probabilites of independent events
# Output:
#   * a list p where p[k] is the probability that exactly k of the events occur
def DistinctBernoulli(eventProbabilities):
__outcomes = []
__for p in eventProbabilities:
____outcomes = AddEvent(outcomes, p)
__return outcomes

The first wave of covid in the UK killed c.40,000 people in three months.  Deaths from the second wave are still materialising, but in just over two months we've lost another 20,000.  Deaths from the second wave are building at a slower rate, likely due to improved treatments and lower viral loads due to social distancing and mask wearing, however covid's long tail and scenes of packed streets full of maskless, non distancing shoppers + a Christmas the public are being encouraged to celebrate mean more 2nd wave deaths & a third wave incoming, irrespective of the vaccine which, for many vulnerable people won't be rolled out until next year. Vaccine prioritisation also means that while surviving over-80s and the medically vulnerable might be safe by March or April, people between 50 and 80 will remain exposed to infection via education & economic policies.  Italy is in a similar situation but with an older population, a big cultural emphasis on Christmas and no prospect of vaccinations until next Spring.  Iran appears to be at the tail end of a massive spike from which deaths may not yet have fully materialised, and is alleging that the US are blocking their access to a vaccine.  Whether this is true or not, no vaccine = no vaccine.  News story this week showed Turkish hospitals struggling to cope with admissions.  Better knowledge of prevention and treatment may stop some of these countries hitting 100k by April 30th, but I'd be surprised if the virus's preference for low temperatures, greater indoor activity, Christmas, anti-vax and anti-lockdown efforts didn't result in at least one or two more countries breaching the third bin.

Sadly, I think it's now very plausible, even likely, that the UK or Italy will pass 100k by the end of their second waves. This is based on the UK's premature abandonment of lockdown, slow rate of reduction of the hospitalization rate, and the fact that daily deaths tend to decrease more slowly on the way down than up, plus the seasons are working against us. With Italy it is based those last 2 points and the height of its current peak, which is only just peaking now, and is just below where it was during the second wave. France could do so on a third wave (or indeed the UK or Italy, if they don't on the second wave), and there is always the possibility that Iran will correct their covered-up data (or indeed they may pass 100k even without that). What is hard to account for is the effect of vaccines. But since these are 2-shot vaccines separated by a 4 week waiting period, and the UK will probably not start vaccinating until next week, and Italy not until January, it would seem that the effect these will have on the death toll of the second wave will be minimal. However we should also consider that while only 2 shots of the vaccine is likely to be enough for 90%+ people to get immunity, it is possible that receiving just the first shot alone (and then getting infected sometime in the following 4 weeks) will be enough to avoid severe symptoms of covid. The UK expects 10m vaccine doses in December, if these are given to the 10m most vulnerable people as 1-shot vaccines (to be followed up with the second dose in January when more vaccine come in), then it is plausible that this could indeed have a significant effect on the total death count. I agree with both @smitch15 and @Bobbiekar52 (mostly). It's probably too big a jump to100k for medium-sized populations or smaller. Going by large population size, Mexico and Russia are the current stand-outs. Yet the latter is plainly under-reporting. Ditto China. Other than a seismic political change in either nation that is likely to remain true until April. And other nations with large populations either have poor quality health care systems that will under-report (Indonesia, Nigeria, Pakistan etc.) or superb systems that have handled the pandemic very well (Japan, Germany). A medium-sized nation could lose control of their outbreak, but that does not necessarily mean deaths will again increase at the same rate. With the medical knowledge gained this year, second wave death rates in Europe are not (so far) spiking as high as in, for example, Italy in March-April. My stand-out concern is Argentina. Its death rate tracks its exponential increase in cases. It needs to be watched carefully.

First things first, it is very clear that Mexico will reach 100k deaths, so this question will almost certainly resolve >=4. There have been about 200 days since COVID became a global pandemic and there are about 200 days until this question resolves. The easiest way to predict, then, is to assume countries ability to control the coronavirus is unchanged, and just double their deaths over the past 200 days as a prediction. That gives a prediction of 4, but a lot of countries (11 I think) reach around 60k-70k deaths.  I think the crowd is underestimating the chance that one of these countries just completely loses control of the virus.
It isn’t just about who will HAVE that many deaths, it is complicated by who will identify and report the deaths.  EG Russia’s ratio of cases to deaths appears to indicate an underreporting.

Mexico is at 87K as of 10-24-20, so it is almost certain to reach higher.  The U.K is at44K. There are several countries around 30K level (France, Spain, Iran, Peru, Argentina, Russia, Columbia) that, after winter and with potential greater re-opening, will have many more cases and potentially more deaths (mitigated by better treatment methods).  It is a slight stretch at the moment to think all will reach this level given better care and potentially inadequate reporting, but it is possible several countries might.  Then if it hits the densely populated countries hard (Bangladesh, Indonesia, Phillipines) and is mismanaged by places such as South Africa, they have a small chance to join the 100K club.  It is unlikely that a vaccine, while it may be developed, will be widely available by then globally.

Some rough mathing on the probability that at least one or two of these other groups break 100k threshold, along with my go-to "it's usually worse than we think it's going to be" heuristic for COVID questions, puts me in the zone of this current forecast.
